mxCell.value: My budget has a new name!
highlight: budget_name
Account Setup Process

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Now click "Create Local Account". Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Checking' and then enter the current balance of that account.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Ready? Select + Add Account!
Got it!

<<Accounts>>

We will start by adding a checking account. For this step, you'll need to log into your bank and see the current balance. Come back to me when you've got that information!
highlight: add_account
Budget Summary Overview
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Let's get familiar with your budget screen. Here you can see the current month as well as previous and future months.
I clicked calendar #3!

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Let's say you want to compare several months at once. Depending on your browser zoom level, you can select up to six months at a time. Please click the third calendar icon.
highlight: calendar_icons
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Now you can view three months. Let's change the view so you can see a different set of months using the purple selection.
highlight: months_band
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget."
highlight: budget_header
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">While you're getting to know MyBudgetCoach, just focus on the amount to budget for now.
How convenient!

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Click on the purple number to see some options for this amount. There are multiple ways to move money around your budget. After all, it's meant to be flexible!
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Let's move onto the next part!
Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create the categories that you need to organize your budget in a way that makes sense for your financial life.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. These categories are fully customizable to meet your own budget needs.
Add Transaction
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">For checking account transactions, payments DECREASE the balance and deposits INCREASE the balance.
Got it!
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Click "+ Add New" and select today's date.
highlight: add_new_button
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">For the category, select "Bills."
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Finish this transaction by selecting the check mark to turn it green.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the starting account balance you entered is $100 less now.
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Let's delete this pretend transaction. Go ahead and hover on the left side of the date to un-hide a box. Select the box to select the transaction.
Got it!

<<Accounts>>

Sounds like a great plan. You can come back to this later by clicking on the 'Start a New Conversation' link right above the 'Schedule Video Call' button and choosing the 'Import Transaction Options' conversation.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">To the right hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options.<br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Select 'Delete' to remove that transaction.

Overview of functionality (Manage Coach Options: Reset / Back button / close out avatar and select conversation to continue /  launching multiple conversations and the in-progress (current one) versus continue conversation (started but not yet completed) versus start a new conversation...); 3-5 blocksðŸ¦<br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Could ask the user a question to understand more about them
highlight: zoom_link

Database - can keep responses and reference later on; not all questions need the database capture. The second line of the response selected is the database code. If not planning to reference answer later or drive flow based on response in another section, don't need second line.

<<Accounts>> / <<Budget>>

This aligns the avatar with which screen the user should be on. If a user goes to the Budget at a step where the avatar flow has <<Accounts>>, or if the user goes to an Account while the avatar is on Budget, the user will see the following message:

 Please navigate to the Accounts {Budget} to continue our conversation (please select an account).

Please Note: There needs to be a blank line between the reference to Accounts/Budget and the text shown in the avatar window.
Link to giphy: https://giphy.com/gifs/filmeditor-movie-comedy-3og0IKinzBYyoia9eE
Welcome [[user_first_name]] to MyBudgetCoach! MyBudgetCoach is a unique budgeting software that comes along with a virtual avatar. You selected, me, Amy, as your personal coach.
Budget Setup

You as the Coach can do as much or as little as you would like for the user. For example, if you just want to add a handful of categories, or walk them through how to edit and add themselves, that is fine. Alternatively, you could have the system build an entire budget with defined groups, and categories, so when they select the button before the template is built, it automatically updates.

Some coaches have built the table in phases, others offer the option of just groups, and the user adds categories, or the user adds everything. Full discretion to the coach!
Much better!
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Are you budgeting with a partner?

YES
partner = yes

NO
partner = no
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">You are the Ruler of your own budget! It's nice to have total control <font style="font-size: 12px;">ðŸ˜€</font>

Next 
partner_name = [user_input]
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Ok great! Please share with me their first name.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Thanks for sharing, [[user_first_name]]. I look forward to helping you and [[partner_name]] develop your budgeting skills!
I'm ready!

<<Accounts>>

Now we are going to practice adding a transaction.
Show me, please!
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">There are just a few more functions to point out on the Account screen.
highlight: filter_button
highlight: search_bar
highlight: split_toggle_button
highlight: more_button
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Type "Cell Phone Company" as your Payee.
highlight: select_payee
highlight: select_category
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Now, enter $100 in the Payment box.
highlight: payment_input

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Now click "Add". <br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Please note, you can select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.
highlight: cleared_status_icon
highlight: save_transaction
highlight: months_band
highlight: budget_table
highlight: category_column

<<Budget>>

The Income row is generally the total amount of deposits to a checking or savings account in a month. 

The Starting Balances row is calculated your first month, but then remains $0 each month after that. You can 'Hide' this category if you choose to after your first month.
highlight: received_column

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">When you hover over the month at the top of the budget summary, two up arrows are shown to the left. Selecting this will collapse the budget summary view to only show the 'To Budget' amount.<br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">You can expand by hovering over the month and then selecting the two down arrows to the left of the month.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">To the right of the month there are three vertical dots. Selecting this shows additional options that can have dollars budgeted to all your categories in one click.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">These options include:<br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">1. Copy last month's budget<br style="font-size: 12px;">2. Set budgets to zero<br style="font-size: 12px;">3. Set budgets to 3 month average
highlight: budget_more_button

All boxes don't need to have <<Accounts>> or <<Budget>>. If you remove this, that means the user can be in either screen and the avatar will continue. This can help with transitions from one section to another.
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Now it's time to talk about budgeting your income. The 'Income' category can be found below your last expense category.
highlight: selected_transactions_button

Order of Walk-Through

Can organize your conversation to have Budget table overview first (no numbers so simpler with less questions) then Accounts OR you could have Accounts first and then have Budget Table.
HelpScout Articles: Footer of MyBudgetCoach.com; Company; Knowledge Base
Budget Skills
Credit Cards get added in a separate conversation. For the Intro, just focus on Checking account. Feel free to let your user know Credit Cards can be added later on in a separate conversation.
Before we get started on creating your personalized budget, I want to show you some important features that will help you navigate the program.
I can't wait to get started!
I'm listening!

You can close this conversation, without losing your place, by hitting the 'x' at the top left of my photo. When you are ready to continue our conversation, click on the conversation bubble above the 'Schedule Video Call' button on the menu at the left side of your screen. You can review a previous step of our conversation by clicking on the 'Back' button.

Take a look at the bottom right corner of our conversation and you will notice 3 vertical dots. Clicking on this will give you the following options:

1) Give Feedback
2) Reset the Conversation
3) End the Conversation

I created this avatar to help you through the process of setting up your budget. Although you cannot ask me questions directly, Avatar Amy will do her best to anticipate any questions you may have and support you along the way.
But what if I want to ask the real Amy a question?

I'm happy you asked! If at any point you would like to schedule a one-on-one coaching session with me, please click on 'Schedule Video Call' button on the left side of your screen and choose a time that works for your schedule.
Sounds great!
Now we're talking!

Note that these coaching sessions do have an hourly fee in addition to the cost of your subscription, but I would be happy to chat with you for the first 30 minutes for free! After our first session, we can schedule additional paid sessions if you need more help.
Got it. Let's get back to work!

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Great name! Remember that you can set up as many budgets as you need to. To close out of the current budget you are working on, click the arrow next to your budget name and click on 'Close file.' From there you will have the option to open a different budget or create a new budget.

First, I want to congratulate you on taking a big step toward achieving your financial goals. Knowing exactly where those hard-earned dollars are going is crucial to a path of financial success. The time and money you are investing now to organize your budget and set these goals for yourself will pay off big-time for the rest of your life. I am excited to work with you on this exciting new journey!

Now that we've gone through some of these basic features, it's time to set up your budget! Getting started with this process is exciting, but you may also feel stressed and overwhelmed at times and that is perfectly normal. You should take as many breaks as you need to stay focused. I will offer suggested breaks as we go along, and you can come back to this conversation when you are refreshed and ready to go again.
I see it!

<<Accounts>>

The account balance is displayed at the top left corner of the account screen. Green indicates a positive balance while red indicates a negative balance.

<<Accounts>>

We are going to start by adding your checking accounts. I will walk you through how to add your accounts and show you how to manage your transactions. Once you categorize your transactions, they will show up in your budget as income or expenses, depending on the transaction. Let's get started!
Head Start!
I'd prefer to set up my own budget categories.
On second thought, let's do this manually.
Full speed ahead!

<<Budget>>

Let's take a closer look at each of these main categories before I show you how to customize them.

<<Budget>>

Fixed Monthly Expenses are recurring monthly expenses that do not vary each month, such as your mortgage payment or car payment. You know exactly how much you need to budget for these expenses.

<<Budget>>

Variable Monthly Expenses are costs that you incur each month, but the amount varies depending on several factors. Some you have control over, such as choosing to dine out less. Some you cannot control, such as the fact that your heating bill will be higher in the winter.
Time to start saving for that epic cross-country RV road trip! <font style="font-size: 30px;">  </font>

<<Budget>>

Future Expenses do not occur on a monthly basis, but if you do not budget for them you risk getting into debt. This is how we budget for those unexpected home maintenance costs that are guaranteed to pop up when you least expect them, or (on a happier note) for that dream vacation you are saving up to take!

<<Budget>>

Now I will show you how to customize this starting budget with your own categories of expenses.

<<Budget>>

Click on the 3 vertical dots to the right of 'Category' at the top left corner of your budget. This gives you visual options. You can show and hide hidden categories and collapse or expand categories within groups.

<<Budget>>

Each row with bold text contains the main groups. Under each group, there are rows of categories within that group.

<<Budget>>

Hover over any category row and you will see a down arrow. When you click this arrow, you have options to hide, rename, or delete that category. For each category group, you also have the option to add a category to that group. You can move categories around by clicking the row and dragging it to a different group.

<<Budget>>

When customizing your spending categories, you can be very detailed or go for a more big-picture approach. There is no end to what categories you can include. I love to go skiing! Skiing is an expensive hobby, so I have a category just for skiing. This is an example of a future expense that I can still budget for all year round. 
â›·ï¸â„ï¸â›·ï¸â„ï¸â›·ï¸â„ï¸â›·ï¸

<<Budget>>

You can add a new main group of expenses by scrolling down to the bottom of the expenses list, just before 'Income,' and click the 'Add Group' button.

<<Accounts>>

Well done setting up your first account! You can set up as many checking accounts as you need for your budget. Later we will learn how to set up your credit card accounts, but for now we are going to move onto the moment you've been waiting for - setting up your new budget!
Let's keep moving!
Nice to meet you!

First, a little about me. I am a pension Actuary and work full-time from my home in the suburbs just outside of D.C. I love travel, exercise, and outdoor adventures and love to share my passions with my two budget breakers...er, I mean children.

Budgeting has helped me to navigate some very stressful financial situations, and I love the sense of control and empowerment that budgeting brings to my life. Whether you are just deciding to take control of your finances or are navigating one of life's many curveballs, I am here to help you along the way.
Link to giphy:  https://giphy.com/gifs/the-most-interesting-man-dos-equis-you-got-this-4Vtk42BGiL1T2
<font style="font-size: 12px;">This is exactly what I came here for!</font>

With My Budget Coach, we are going to be using a budgeting system known as 'Zero-based' budgeting. This is a powerful system that will help you prioritize your spending, eliminate unnecessary expenses, and pay off debt. Pretty cool, huh?
<font style="font-size: 12px;">Every dollar has a job ðŸ¤‘</font>
Every dollar of your income will be allocated to different expense categories - this includes debt payments and saving for future expenses. You are about to put your money to work!
Sounds like a great strategy.
It will be important for you to monitor your budget throughout the month. I track my income and expenses twice a month, but you can also consider doing this more frequently, such as weekly.
I want to stay on track!

This method of budgeting will ensure that every dollar you earn is purposefully allocated to the expenses that you need to prioritize. This will help you live within your means and work toward achieving your long-term financial goals.

Now that you know what you are in for, let's get to work! Here is what we will cover:

1. Account Tour & Checking Account Setup
2. How to Add Transactions 
3. Budget Tour & Setup
4. Budget Skills
5. Credit Card Accounts
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">You can also split a transaction if one transaction covers multiple categories of expenses. Let's practice this.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Add a new transaction, and this time for the Payee type 'Costco.' In the Category box, select 'Split Transaction.' Type $200 in the 'Payment' box.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">In the next 'Category' box, type 'Food' and type $100 in the corresponding payment box.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Click 'Add Split' and categorize the next $100 payment as 'General.' Then click the 'Add' button.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Note the split toggle button in the upper right corner of your screen. Click on this and you will see the split transaction expand or contract from view.
I deleted it.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">You can now delete this practice transaction.

<<Budget>>

The 'To Budget' amount at the top of your screen is the dollars you have to allocate to your expense categories. For the first month, it is the starting balance, plus income earned throughout the month, minus the amount you've budgeted to your expense categories.

<<Budget>>

Click on the 'To Budget' number and select 'Move to a category.' Now you can start putting your money to work by assigning an expense category to each dollar to be budgeted. Alternatively, you can enter the amount to be budgeted for each category directly to the 'Budgeted' column for that category.

<<Budget>>

If you have debt you are working on paying off, you should create a 'Debt' category and budget for the payments you need to make.
I need a plan of attack!

<<Budget>>

You should budget at least the minimum payment for each debt category. If you are serious about becoming debt-free, there are several different approaches you can take, such as concentrating on your highest interest rate debt first or getting rid of the debt with the lowest balance first.

<<Budget>>

You also want to be sure to budget for any debt payments, other than your monthly mortgage payments. Do you have other debt, such as car payments, credit card debt, or student loans?
That would be life-changing!

<<Budget>>

If you need help developing a plan, you can book a one-on-one call with me and we can discuss some options and come up with a strategy that works best for your unique situation. No matter how overwhelmed you may feel, it is possible to be free of those pesky payments once and for all!
Link to https://giphy.com/gifs/freedom-braveheart-musical-theater-6901DbEbbm4o0

<<Budget>>

Paying close attention to your budget so you do not end up spending more than your income will ensure that you remain debt-free.

<<Budget>>

As I mentioned earlier, if this is your first time creating a budget and tracking your spending habits, it may take at least 3 months before you have a solid idea of what you actually need to budget for each category. You can adjust these 'Budgeted' amounts as needed in future months.

<<Budget>>

As you allocate income to expenses, you will see the 'To Budget' number decrease. If you budget more money than you have available, this number will turn red and show a negative amount.
What does this mean?

<<Budget>>

Keep in mind that you started your budget between the beginning and end of the month, you should prorate the amount to be budgeted to each category.
That makes sense!

<<Budget>>

Let's say you started your budget on the 16th of the month and there are 30 days in the month you started your budget (so there are 15 days remaining in the month). If you wanted to budget $500/month for groceries, for that first partial month you should budget $500 x 15/30 = $250 for groceries.
Budget responsibly. Got it!

<<Budget>>

Remember to keep your priorities in check when assigning your dollars to expenses. You need to make sure that your basic needs (housing, food, utilities, childcare, etc.) are covered before you budget to the things you want, such as a vacation.
I will be sure to monitor my spending habits!

<<Budget>>

Now that you understand how to set up your budget, let's take a closer look at how MyBudgetCoach can allow for flexibility within your budget.
Dance Break!
Let's keep going!

<<Budget>>

Time for another progress check! Look at you go you Budget Beast!

1. Account Tour & Checking Account Setup
2. How to Add Transactions 
3. Budget Tour & Setup
4. Budget Skills
5. Credit Card Accounts

This is a good break point if you need to take a break and pick this conversation back up later. Do you need to recharge or would you like to keep chugging along?
Ok, I'm ready now!
You can resume this conversation whenever you are ready to!
...one last thing before I leave you to your budgeting...
Of course
Can you answer 3 short questions for me? I want to make sure I continue to improve how helpful I am!
I submitted the form
Great! Here's the link: https://airtable.com/appYAaDkGzB3ecOzl/shrUnpE9sHBWWDMyB
Thanks so much! Happy budgeting!
User Survey after Tutorial

<font style="font-size: 12px;">Thank you for giving me the opportunity to work with you. Please feel free to send me a message if you have any questions or issues while working through this tutorial. Note the 'Message Center' button at the bottom of the menu to the left.</font>

<font style="font-size: 12px;">For bigger issues, or if you would like a one-on-one coaching session, please book a call by clicking on the 'Schedule Video Call' button at the bottom of the menu to the left.    </font>
Don't Edit - Keep link and keep text
This is the end of the introduction conversation. A user can reset the conversation under the Manage Coach section.

<<Budget>>

You've made it to the finish line! Once again, here is a list of everything we covered today:

1. Account Tour & Checking Account Setup
2. How to Add Transactions 
3. Budget Tour & Setup
4. Budget Skills
5. Credit Card Accounts

Now it's time to start putting your money to work for you and think about your long-term financial goals. Accumulating wealth is a long process but remember that every decision you make matters. Deciding to get serious about budgeting and learning how to use the MyBudgetCoach software is a huge step toward your successful financial future.
highlight: zoom_link
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Thanks for your answer! Let's add one more account to capture your total expenses.

<<Accounts>>

Select "+Add Account", click "Create Local Account."

Name your account, select a Type of "For Budget: Credit Card", and then enter the current balance of that account.
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">You want to plan on Budgeting dollars to make a payment of at least your minimum payment for each account.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Thanks for your answer! Let's now add the credit card account that is used the most often of your remaining accounts.

<<Accounts>>

Select "+Add Account", click "Create Local Account."

Name your account, select a Type of "For Budget: Credit Card", and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Accounts>>

Now that we've added your credit card accounts, next I am going to show you how to add transactions to these accounts.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">How many transactions per <u style="font-size: 12px;">week</u> occur on your remaining credit card account?

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.
highlight: selected_transactions_button

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">As you continue to use MyBudgetCoach, please keep in mind each account requires reconciliation, a few times a month, and categorizing of transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Rather than adding transactions manually, you can import your transactions in bulk. To do this, you will need to go to your credit card company account and download your activity for the date range you are working on. Save this as a CSV file. Keep in mind that expense transactions should show as a negative number in the file and any transactions that reduce the credit card balance (payments, rewards, etc.) should show as a positive number. You may need to adjust this prior to importing the file. When you are ready, click the 'Import' button at the top menu and select the file you downloaded.
Got it
5 or Less transactions

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Because you will be carrying some debt over to next month, there are a few additional steps we will walk through to make sure MyBudgetCoach works properly for you.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">If at a later point you would like to add additional credit card accounts, you can select this conversation again to start from the beginning.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Based on the number of transactions that occur per week, I would recommend leaving out the additional account for now, and then if you would like to add it on a future date, feel free!
Yes; Let's review those steps again

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Based on the number of transactions that occur per week, let's add one more account so your expenses can be accurately captured each month.
No; All set

Congratulations on setting up a credit card in the Budget!<br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Is there another Credit Card account where you would like to walk through the Budget set-up process again?
Let's now move to Step 2. For this, we will shift from the Budget to the Accounts section and select a credit card account.
More than 5 transactions
Ok! My credit card account category has been added. Step 1 complete!
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">To summarize, you have added three credit card accounts.

<<Budget>>

Sure; Before we review those steps again, please create a new category within your Credit Card Group and name that category with the Credit Card Account name.
highlight: balance column
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">How many additional credit<br style="font-size: 12px;">cards do you actively use each week?
Got it!

<<Budget>>

Now that you have added credit card account(s), your 'To Budget' number has been reduced by the total of the balance for the account(s) you just added. Let's walk through how to make the 'To Budget' number equal to what it was prior to adding the credit card account(s).
Two or more

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Let's add your credit card account that is the most used card first.<br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance. Come back to me when you've got that information!
highlight: add_account

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.
move_to: budget_header
highlight: add_account
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.
highlight: zoom_link
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Before we link a third credit card account, let me ask a follow-up question.
highlight: add_account

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Because you can pay the balance in-full, and have a credit card category with a 'Balance' = 0, moving forward with your MyBudgetCoach use, you will be funding your categories outside of the credit card category. If you aren't accumulating any debt, have covered any overspent categories, then your credit card payment will be equal to your current balance.
highlight: add_account

For the credit card account(s) you added, are there any that you plan to pay off the current balance at the end of this month?<br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Please note, by 'current balance' I am referring to the balance you entered when you added the account. This is <u style="font-size: 12px;">not</u> the statement balance, which is a balance as of an earlier date.
You can complete the 'Calculate Credit Card Payment' conversation at any time to assist in determining what your credit card payment should be.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Give yourself some grace and remember, reducing your debt is a journey and takes dedication. You already have started working toward your goal by using this budgeting software and working through this conversation to learn more!
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">If you have more than one credit card account, you will need to complete the following steps for each account.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Step 1 is to create a Group called 'Credit Cards.' Under that Group, you would add a category for each of the credit card account(s) you added. You can also add these credit card categories to the 'Debt' group if you've already created that group.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">The first transaction should be the 'Starting Balance' transaction that was added when you first added the account. You should see an amount in the 'Payment' column that equals the balance on the day you added the account.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Now that we have created the category on the Budget for the Credit Card Account, we are going to change the Category from 'Starting Balance' to the newly created category for your Credit Card Account.
Great work! Now, lets go back to the Budget and see what happened with the 'Spent' and 'Balance' columns in the Credit Card Account category.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Scroll down to the credit card category of the account you just updated. Now the 'Spent' column is a negative number that equals your balance you entered previously.
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Since the 'Budgeted' column for the category is 0, the 'Balance' is a negative red number and is equal to 'Spent.'
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">The last step, Step 3, is to complete the actions for how you want MyBudgetCoach to handle the debt associated with the credit card. You have some options, so let me first ask you a question so I can tailor my guidance.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Good for you! KUDOS on managing your debt. Very few people with a credit card balance have the cash flow to pay in-full at any time.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">To fund your balance you enter the amount of your credit card balance in the Budgeted column of your newly created credit card category. This will update the 'Balance' to be 0 since you budgeted dollars to equal the current balance of the credit card.
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">When you Budgeted the dollars, the purple number at the top of the Budget Summary in the 'To Budget' went down.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">You can now budget with confidence the rest of your available dollars to your remaining categories, until your 'To Budget' number is 0. If you would like to learn more about this process, select the 'Make To Budget Equal to 0' conversation to work through that conversation when you have completed this conversation.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">We need to allow the remaining balance you don't pay off this current month, to continue to future months, since your credit card company will continue to have that balance carry over until you pay it off.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">MyBudgetCoach has a unique feature that is called 'Rollover overspending.' This option allows a user to have the debt continue into future months, instead of paying off this month, so you can pay it off over time.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Selecting the 'Rollover overspending' option increases your 'To Budget' number in the current month, since the debt has now been rolled over to future months.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Select the negative amount in red text in the Balance column of your Credit Card Account Category. Within the option menu that comes up, select the 'Rollover overspending' option.<br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">To see the system roll the debt over to a future month, select the option in the top left to show two months at a time by selecting the 2nd calendar icon.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">The arrow to the right of the amount in the Balance column is how MyBudgetCoach alerts you to the fact you have rolled over the overspending for future months. This option will stay turned on for all future months, unless you select to 'Remove overspending rollover.'

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">When you budget to the category it reduces the debt immediately. You'll still have to submit a payment through your credit card account, but you can see your progress in the category right away.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Credit Cards can be complex, especially if you have more than one credit card account. I am available for a one-on-one call at your convenience to help answer any questions you may have in your future use of MyBudgetCoach.
Opposite from my bank account. Got it!

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">The important difference between a bank account and a credit card account is that for a credit card account, Payments INCREASE the balance, and Deposits DECREASE the balance. This is because a credit card balance is negative.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Please select your main credit card account. You will now add two hypothetical transactions.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Please select '+ Add New,' select today's date and enter a Payee of 'Cell Phone Company.'

<<Accounts>>

Select an applicable category and enter a Payment amount of 100, Clear the transaction by clicking the checkmark on the right to green, and select Add.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Let's now add a transaction for a credit card payment. Credit Card payments are Transfers and entered as a Deposit.

<<Accounts>>

The credit card balance, a red negative number, has now increased by 100, resulting in a higher negative number.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Please select '+ Add New,' select today's date, and for the Payee, select 'Make Transfer.' Within the 'Transfer To/From' list of accounts, select your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

The Category field is now populated with Transfer. Enter 100 in the 'Deposit' field, since this is a payment to reduce the credit card balance, and select Add.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Let's now jump over to the checking account.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Note that the credit card payment is an outflow in the Payment column for the checking account, but an inflow in the Deposit column for the credit card. This is because your payment reduces a negative balance (Deposit) in the credit card account and reduces the positive balance (Payment) in the checking account.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">KUDOS on creating transactions for both accounts!
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Before we move to the next step, let's delete those two credit card transactions you added.

<<Accounts>>

Please navigate back to your main credit card account and select each of the two transactions using the box to the left of the date. Then select the link named '2 transactions' to the right of the search bar and choose Delete.
highlight: add_new_button
Great work setting up your Credit Card accounts in MyBudgetCoach! Now it's time to wrap things up!

Now that you've learned how to add credit card transactions, we are going to see how everything comes together by taking a look at the impact to the Budget Summary and Table as a result of adding credit card account(s).
The 'launch conversation' does not work.

<<Accounts>>

Now your transactions are automatically populated and you can work on organizing these transactions into the corresponding budget categories you created. If you need additional help with this, you can book a one-on-one call and we can walk through this together.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">First, let's give your budget a name! Click the arrow next to the current budget name, click on 'Rename Budget,' and change it to something that will identify the current budget you are working on. You may want to include the month and year that you started your budget as part of the name.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Now let's get down to business. We are going to learn how to set up your own budget.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Now let's tailor these categories to fit your own budget. You have 2 options - I can give you a head start by setting you up with my preferred way of categorizing my expenses, or you can start from scratch and manually add your own categories. Which would you prefer?

<<Budget>>

Here's your fancy new budget! You will be able to customize this starting budget as much as you need to fit your own needs.

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

Link to giphy:

https://giphy.com/gifs/pudgypenguins-rich-stock-stonks-M9USyermmmO8WJG6FK
highlight: budgeted_column
<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars.
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.
highlight: balance_column
I hope this doesn't happen!

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card.
I will keep that in mind.

<<Budget>>

There will most definitely be months where you overspend in one or more of your budget categories. Don't panic! Keep in mind that if this is the first time you've gotten serious about keeping track of your budget, it may take about 3 months to set reasonable 'Budgeted' amounts for your variable categories, such as groceries and dining out.

<<Budget>>

You will have the option to transfer any part of the positive balance of a different category to cover the overspending.  More on this later!
That will come in handy!

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">This is the 'Search' bar. As you type, whether text or numbers, the list of transactions will dynamically filter down based on criteria entered.
Good to know!

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">The 'Undo' and 'Redo' buttons are helpful tools when you are working in this screen.<br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">Please note: These are also available in the Budget screen as well. However, when selected, they will 'Undo' or 'Redo' your last action completed for either Accounts or Budget, depending on where your last action was.
<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">The 'Filter' button allows you to filter down the transactions you are viewing by certain criteria (date, payee, category...).
That's a useful feature!
I'd like to stick to the basics for now!

<<Accounts>>

These three dots show additional options. Click on the 'Show Running Balance' option. This will show the resulting balance after each transaction.
No credit cards for me!

Alright, now I am going to show you how to add your credit card accounts. For many of us, this is where the majority of our spending occurs. If you do not use credit cards, you can skip past this part. Do you have credit card accounts to add?

<<Budget>>

No problem. Let me walk you through organizing your own categories.

link to giphy:

https://giphy.com/gifs/ShalitaGrant-adult-adulting-shalita-grant-1oGpr1CkUDpAM2yT5Z

Let's practice! Enter $500 in the 'Budgeted' column of your 'Grocery' category, and $300 in the 'Budgeted column of your 'Dining Out' category. You can create these categories if needed. Now click on your checking account and create a payment transaction categorized as 'Grocery' for $300. Move back over to your budget screen and you will see that your balance in the 'Grocery' category decreased by $300 and you have $200 left to spend for the month.

Now return to the Accounts screen. Hover on the left side of the date corresponding to the last 'Grocery' transaction you created to un-hide a box. Select the box to select the transaction. To the right-hand side of the search box at the top of the screen, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options. Select 'Duplicate transaction' to create another $300 Grocery transaction.

Click on the red negative $100 and click 'Cover Overspending.' You still have $200 in the 'Dining Out' category that you did not spend, so enter 'Dining Out' as the 'Cover from category.' Click 'Transfer.'

Now you will see that your 'Budgeted' amount for the 'Grocery' category has increased by $100 to $600, the 'Balance' column for this category is zero, and the 'Budgeted' amount for the 'Dining Out' category has decreased by $100.

This demonstrates how you can cover overspending in one category with underspent amounts in a different category. You can remove those practice 'Budgeted' amounts and delete the 2 transactions we just created. Now let's take a look at how we would use the 'Rollover Overspending' option.

Let's say that you owe $1,200 in insurance, paid annually, and this amount is due next month. You budget $100 for this each month. First, click the third calendar icon to show 3 months of your budget, then click the current month to be the first month.

Notice that, while the 'Spent' columns are zero for this category, MyBudgetCoach automatically rolls over the amount not spent to the following month. By the third month, you see a balance of $300 for this category.
highlight: calendar_icons
Now go back to your checking account and create a payment transaction of $1,200 categorized as 'Insurance' with the payment date in the second month.
Return to your 'Budget' screen, and now you see a red negative $1,000 balance for the 'Insurance' category in the second month.

Click on the red negative number and then click the 'Rollover overspending' option. Now notice how the following month's balance shows a red negative $900. This balance will increase by $100 until the entire $1,200 expense has been budgeted for.

<<Budget>>

It's nice to have this flexibility, but you need to make sure that you have the money to cover any overspending. Otherwise, you risk going into debt. If you find that you are consistently exceeding your budget in certain categories, it may be time to reevaluate your spending habits and make changes to bring them in line with your financial goals.
In the 'Budgeted' column for the 'Insurance' category, enter $100 for both the current month and the following two months. You can add this category if needed.
highlight: selected_transactions_button
Return to the Budget screen and notice that now you balance in the 'Grocery' category shows a red negative $100. This means that you've overspent in this category.
Ready to get back to the Introduction!

Please click on 'Start a New Conversation' right above the 'Schedule Video Call' button on the left-side menu. Then choose the 'Import Transaction Options' conversation. You can come back to this conversation when you are ready.

<<Accounts>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">You will also notice the 'Link account' option in this list of additional options. I showed you how to add individual transactions manually, but there are more efficient methods of importing your transactions from your bank. Would you like to learn more about this now?

<<Budget>><br style="font-size: 12px;"><br style="font-size: 12px;">This will automatically update your budget template. You will still be able to change and move categories around as much as you need to.
Thanks for the tip!

If you need to run a quick question by me, you can send me a message using the Message Center at the very bottom of the left-side menu. I will reply as soon as I can but within 2 business days. In addition to any messages we exchange, as you complete these conversations, your progress and selections will be shown within the Message Center in a chat format.

<<Accounts>>

Which Option would you like to learn more about?
SIMPLE FIN
Direct Import
Bulk Import

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for that information. Direct Import within MyBudgetCoach has some great benefits. For example, the starting balance for linked accounts is automatically set and the system includes three prior days worth of transactions to get you started.

<<Accounts>>

Direct Import removes the additional tasks of having to manually upload transactions. Each time you log in, the system will automatically have added recent transactions.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach uses machine learning, so as you continue to use the system, the system will automatically apply proposed categories to new transactions and the manual steps to categorize transactions will lessen over time.

<<Accounts>>

To increase your security, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with a third-party service, SimpleFIN, to link your accounts. SimpleFIN uses a well-established connection software called 'MX' to connect your bank account financial institutions to SimpleFIN.

<<Accounts>>

To connect SimpleFIN to MyBudgetCoach, there is a one-time code produced by SimpleFIN to enter into MyBudgetCoach. The accounts you link in SimpleFIN will then become available to link to already existing accounts within MyBudgetCoach to start Direct Import.

<<Accounts>>

Please note SimpleFIN does have a small additional fee: $1.50 per month, or $15 per year (not including tax, if applicable). This is paid separately from your MyBudgetCoach subscription and is paid through SimpleFIN, not within MyBudgetCoach.
I'm good, thanks!

<<Accounts>>

The Bulk Import process requires you to export/download transactions from your financial institution in a 'csv' file format.
Have you completed an export of transactions from a bank or credit card account before?

<<Accounts>>

Understood! I think it would be best to talk through this further during a one-on-one call with me. I would be happy to walk you through the steps to complete the export of transactions and how to load them to MyBudgetCoach.
Ok great! Are you familiar with how to edit column headings and re-arrange amounts in columns within Excel?

<<Accounts>>

Be sure your columns are organized in the following order:

Date / Payee / Notes / Category (blank) / Amount

The amount can either be one column, or split into separate columns, one for Payments and one for Deposits.

MyBudgetCoach can also split up the amount column into two separate columns by splitting the positive and negative values.

<<Accounts>>

Once you have your data organized the correct way, use the 'Import' button to select your csv file to upload. Follow along the MyBudgetCoach screen to select the appropriate column in your csv file to map to the correct MyBudgetCoach field.

<<Accounts>>

Great job importing your transactions! You can complete these steps at your chosen frequency. I recommend at least once a week until you become comfortable with the software.
Bulk Import

There are three options:

Option 1: Adding transactions manually (the Introduction conversation walked through this process),

Option 2: Direct Import - using a third-party bank connection software, SimpleFIN. Once completed, when you select 'Sync' transactions will automatically be brought into MyBudgetCoach for all accounts.

Option 3: Bulk Import - uploading exports of transactions from your bank to MyBudgetCoach to add transactions in bulk for each account.
highlight: zoom_link
Ok; I just booked a video call
I'm confident I will help you export and upload your transactions.
I'm good, thanks!

<<Accounts>>

To link an existing account added prior, select that account, and then to the right of the search box, select the three horizontal dots and choose 'Link account' from the options shown.

<<Accounts>>

Would you like to go back to see the other options again?

<<Accounts>>

Would you like to go back to see the other options again?

<<Accounts>>

 Next select the 'Link bank account with SimpleFIN' button. After that, select the 'Setup bank sync' purple button next to the account you want to link.

<<Accounts>>

Would you like to go back to see the other options again?
I'm good, thanks!

<<Accounts>>

You will then be brought to the SimpleFIN homepage. Create an account, complete payment for the subscription, link your bank account(s), and then add a connection called 'MyBudgetCoach.'
highlight: import_button
Okay, let's walk through the different methods for adding transactions within MyBudgetCoach.
